org.magicdgs.readtools.tools.conversion

Class StandardizeReads

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.broadinstitute.hellbender.cmdline.CommandLineProgram
      • org.magicdgs.readtools.engine.ReadToolsProgram
        • org.magicdgs.readtools.engine.ReadToolsWalker
          • org.magicdgs.readtools.tools.conversion.StandardizeReads
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    org.broadinstitute.barclay.argparser.CommandLinePluginProvider

    @DocumentedFeature
public final class StandardizeReads
extends ReadToolsWalker
    General tool for standardize any kind of read source (both raw and mapped reads).

    This tool outputs a SAM/BAM/CRAM file as defined in the SAM specifications:

    • Quality encoding: the Standard quality is Sanger. Quality is detected automatically, but it could be forced with --forceEncoding
    • Raw barcodes: the standard barcode tags are BC for the sequence and QT for the quality. To correctly handle information in a SAM/BAM/CRAM file with misencoded barcode tags, one of the following options could be used:
      • Barcodes in the read name: use --barcodeInReadName option. This may be useful for files produced by mapping a multiplexed library stored as FASTQ files.
      • Barcodes in a different tag(s): use --rawBarcodeSequenceTags. This may be useful if the barcode is present in a different tag (e.g., when using illumina2bam with dual indexing, the second index will be in the B2 tag)
    • FASTQ file(s): the output is an unmapped SAM/BAM/CRAM file with the quality header added to the CO tag. The raw barcode is extracted from the read name if present independently of the read name encoding (Casava or Illumina legacy). In the case of the Casava's read name encoding, the PF binary tag is also updated.
    ReadTools.note:
    FASTQ files does not require the --barcodeInReadName option.
    ReadTools.warning:
    If several barcode indexes are present, barcodes are separated by hyphens and qualities by space as defined in the SAM specifications.

      • closeTool

        public void closeTool()
        Description copied from class: ReadToolsWalker
        This method is called by the framework at the end of the ReadToolsWalker.doWork() template method. It is called regardless of whether the ReadToolsWalker.traverse() has succeeded or not. It is called after the ReadToolsWalker.onTraversalSuccess() has completed (successfully or not) but before the ReadToolsWalker.doWork() method returns. In other words, on successful runs both ReadToolsWalker.onTraversalSuccess() and ReadToolsWalker.closeTool() will be called (in this order) while on failed runs (when ReadToolsWalker.traverse() causes an exception), only ReadToolsWalker.closeTool() will be called. The default implementation does nothing. Subclasses should override this method to close any resources that must be closed regardless of the success of traversal.
        Overrides:
        closeTool in class ReadToolsWalker
